message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The SCIP Optimization Suite 7.0
Paper Abstract: The SCIP Optimization Suite provides a collection of software packages for mathematical optimization centered around the constraint integer programming framework SCIP. This paper discusses enhancements and extensions contained in version 7.0 of the SCIP Optimization Suite. The new version features the parallel presolving library PaPILO as a new addition to the suite. PaPILO 1.0 simplifies mixed-integer linear optimization problems and can be used stand-alone or integrated into SCIP via a presolver plugin. SCIP 7.0 provides additional support for decomposition algorithms. Besides improvements in the Benders’ decomposition solver of SCIP, user-defined decomposition structures can be read, which are used by the automated Benders’ decomposition solver and two primal heuristics. Additionally, SCIP 7.0 comes with a tree size estimation that is used to predict the completion of the overall solving process and potentially trigger restarts. Moreover, substantial performance improvements of the MIP core were achieved by new developments in presolving, primal heuristics, branching rules, conflict analysis, and symmetry handling. Last, not least, the report presents updates to other components and extensions of the SCIP Optimization Suite, in particular, the LP solver SoPlex and the mixed-integer semidefinite programming solver SCIP-SDP.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "mixed-integer linear programming"

Links: [{"title":"Integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"lp_solve - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lp_solve"},{"title":"Integer linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Integer_linear_programming&redirect=no"}]

## Mixed-Integer Linear Programming

Mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) is a type of problem where only some of the unknown variables are required to be integers. If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.

### Applications

Mixed-integer programming has diverse practical applications:

- Mixed-integer programming has many applications in industrial productions, including job-shop modelling
- Agricultural production planning involves determining production yield for several crops that can share resources (e.g. land, labor, capital, seeds, fertilizer, etc.), with the objective to maximize total production without exceeding available resources, which can be expressed as a linear program with integer-constrained variables
- Transportation problems involve service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks, such as assigning buses or subways to individual routes to meet timetables and equip them with drivers

### Solution Methods

One class of algorithms are cutting plane methods, which work by solving the LP relaxation and then adding linear constraints that drive the solution towards being integer without excluding any integer feasible points. Another class of algorithms are variants of the branch and bound method, such as the branch and cut method that combines both branch and bound and cutting plane methods.

Web search results for query: "conflict analysis SAT solver"

Links: [{"title":"SAT solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAT_solver"},{"title":"Conflict-driven clause learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conflict-driven_clause_learning"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_problem"},{"title":"Satisfiability modulo theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SMT_solver"},{"title":"DPLL algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DPLL_algorithm"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability algorithm heuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_algorithm_heuristics"},{"title":"Category:SAT solvers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:SAT_solvers"},{"title":"ZYpp - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zypper"},{"title":"Constraint satisfaction problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_satisfaction_problem"},{"title":"2-satisfiability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2-satisfiability"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about conflict analysis in SAT solvers:

## Conflict Analysis in SAT Solvers

Conflict-driven solvers, such as conflict-driven clause learning (CDCL), augment the basic DPLL search algorithm with efficient conflict analysis, clause learning, backjumping, a "two-watched-literals" form of unit propagation, adaptive branching, and random restarts.

### How Conflict Analysis Works

Conflict analysis identifies new clauses using the resolution operation. Therefore, each learnt clause can be inferred from the original clauses and other learnt clauses by a sequence of resolution steps.

### Key Properties

Clause learning with conflict analysis affects neither soundness nor completeness. This means the solver maintains its correctness guarantees while adding learning capabilities.

### Practical Significance

These "extras" to the basic systematic search have been empirically shown to be essential for handling the large SAT instances that arise in electronic design automation (EDA). Most state-of-the-art SAT solvers are based on the CDCL framework as of 2019.(no content)The CDCL algorithm has made SAT solvers so powerful that they are being used effectively in several real world application areas like AI planning, bioinformatics, software test pattern generation, software package dependencies, hardware and software model checking, and cryptography.

Benders - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_F._Benders"},{"title":"Category:Decomposition methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Decomposition_methods"},{"title":"Benders (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benders_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Bender's method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bender's_method"},{"title":"B-Bender - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/StringBender"},{"title":"Benderama - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benderama"},{"title":"Decomposition of a module - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decomposition_of_a_module"},{"title":"Bender (Futurama) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bender_Bending_Rodriguez"}]

## Benders Decomposition

Benders decomposition is a technique in mathematical programming that allows the solution of very large linear programming problems that have a special block structure.(no content)This block structure often occurs in applications such as stochastic programming as the uncertainty is usually represented with scenarios.

### How It Works

The strategy behind Benders decomposition can be summarized as divide-and-conquer. In Benders decomposition, the variables of the original problem are divided into two subsets so that a first-stage master problem is solved over the first set of variables, and the values for the second set of variables are determined in a second-stage subproblem for a given first-stage solution.(no content)If the subproblem determines that the fixed first-stage decisions are in fact infeasible, then so-called Benders cuts are generated and added to the master problem, which is then re-solved until no cuts can be generated.

### Method Classification

Since Benders decomposition adds new constraints as it progresses towards a solution, the approach is called "row generation". In contrast, Dantzig–Wolfe decomposition uses "column generation".

### Historical Context

The technique is named after Jacques F. Benders.(no content)He developed the technique known as Benders' decomposition, and used the results in his doctoral thesis.

Links: [{"title":"Semidefinite programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semidefinite_programming"},{"title":"Talk:Semidefinite programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Semidefinite_programming"},{"title":"Semidefinite embedding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semidefinite_embedding"},{"title":"Second-order cone programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second-order_cone_programming"},{"title":"Quantum Fisher information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Fisher_information"},{"title":"Quantum optimization algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_semidefinite_programming"},{"title":"Spectrahedron - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrahedron"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of semidefinite programming:

## Definition

Semidefinite programming (SDP) is a subfield of mathematical programming concerned with the optimization of a linear objective function over the intersection of the cone of positive semidefinite matrices with an affine space, i.e., a spectrahedron.

## Key Characteristics

SDPs are a special case of cone programming and can be efficiently solved by interior point methods.(no content)All linear programs and (convex) quadratic programs can be expressed as SDPs, and via hierarchies of SDPs the solutions of polynomial optimization problems can be approximated.

## Applications

Semidefinite programming has numerous practical applications:

- Many practical problems in operations research and combinatorial optimization can be modeled or approximated as semidefinite programming problems.
- In automatic control theory, SDPs are used in the context of linear matrix inequalities.
- Semidefinite programs are important tools for developing approximation algorithms for NP-hard maximization problems.
- SDPs are also used in geometry to determine tensegrity graphs, and arise in control theory as LMIs, and in inverse elliptic coefficient problems as convex, non-linear, semidefiniteness constraints. It is also widely used in physics to constrain conformal field theories with the conformal bootstrap.

## Solution Methods

First-order methods for conic optimization avoid computing, storing and factorizing a large Hessian matrix and scale to much larger problems than interior point methods, at some cost in accuracy. A first-order method is implemented in the Splitting Cone Solver (SCS). Another first-order method is the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM).

Based on the search results, here's an overview of semidefinite programming:

## Definition

Semidefinite programming (SDP) is a subfield of mathematical programming concerned with the optimization of a linear objective function over the intersection of the cone of positive semidefinite matrices with an affine space, i.e., a spectrahedron.

## Key Characteristics

SDPs are a special case of cone programming and can be efficiently solved by interior point methods.(no content)All linear programs and (convex) quadratic programs can be expressed as SDPs, and via hierarchies of SDPs the solutions of polynomial optimization problems can be approximated.

## Applications

Semidefinite programming has numerous practical applications:

- Many practical problems in operations research and combinatorial optimization can be modeled or approximated as semidefinite programming problems.
- In automatic control theory, SDPs are used in the context of linear matrix inequalities.
- Semidefinite programs are important tools for developing approximation algorithms for NP-hard maximization problems.
- SDPs are also used in geometry to determine tensegrity graphs, and arise in control theory as LMIs, and in inverse elliptic coefficient problems as convex, non-linear, semidefiniteness constraints. It is also widely used in physics to constrain conformal field theories with the conformal bootstrap.

## Solution Methods

First-order methods for conic optimization avoid computing, storing and factorizing a large Hessian matrix and scale to much larger problems than interior point methods, at some cost in accuracy. A first-order method is implemented in the Splitting Cone Solver (SCS). Another first-order method is the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM).

Web search results for query: "heuristic algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Heuristic (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Category:Heuristic algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Heuristic_algorithms"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability algorithm heuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_algorithm_heuristics"},{"title":"Heuristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic"},{"title":"Admissible heuristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Admissible_heuristic"},{"title":"Hyper-heuristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyper-heuristic"},{"title":"Metaheuristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaheuristic"},{"title":"Heuristic routing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic_routing"},{"title":"A* search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm"},{"title":"Guided local search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guided_local_search"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about heuristic algorithms:

## Definition

A heuristic is a technique designed for problem solving more quickly when classic methods are too slow for finding an exact or approximate solution, or when classic methods fail to find any exact solution in a search space.(no content)This is achieved by trading optimality, completeness, accuracy, or precision for speed.

## Purpose and Characteristics

The objective of a heuristic is to produce a solution in a reasonable time frame that is good enough for solving the problem at hand.(no content)This solution may not be the best of all the solutions to this problem, or it may simply approximate the exact solution. But it is still valuable because finding it does not require a prohibitively long time.

## How Heuristics Work

A heuristic function, also simply called a heuristic, is a function that ranks alternatives in search algorithms at each branching step based on available information to decide which branch to follow.(no content)Heuristics may produce results by themselves, or they may be used in conjunction with optimization algorithms to improve their efficiency (e.g., they may be used to generate good seed values).

## Real-World Significance

Results about NP-hardness in theoretical computer science make heuristics the only viable option for a variety of complex optimization problems that need to be routinely solved in real-world applications.

## Example

For the travelling salesman problem, the greedy algorithm can be used to give a good but not optimal solution (it is an approximation to the optimal answer) in a reasonably short amount of time.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of constraint integer programming:

## Definition

An integer programming problem is a mathematical optimization or feasibility program in which some or all of the variables are restricted to be integers. In many settings the term refers to integer linear programming (ILP), in which the objective function and the constraints (other than the integer constraints) are linear.

## Key Concepts

A constraint is a condition of an optimization problem that the solution must satisfy. There are several types of constraints—primarily equality constraints, inequality constraints, and integer constraints.(no content)If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.

## Computational Complexity

Integer programming is NP-complete (the difficult part is showing the NP membership).

## Solution Methods

Several algorithms are used to solve integer programming problems:

- Cutting plane methods work by solving the LP relaxation and then adding linear constraints that drive the solution towards being integer without excluding any integer feasible points.

- Another class of algorithms are variants of the branch and bound method. For example, the branch and cut method that combines both branch and bound and cutting plane methods.

## Applications

These problems involve service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks. For example, a problem may involve assigning buses or subways to individual routes so that a timetable can be met, and also to equip them with drivers.

Links: [{"title":"Symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Chiral symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiral_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Spontaneous symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"1964 PRL symmetry breaking papers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1964_PRL_symmetry_breaking_papers"},{"title":"Explicit symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Symmetry-breaking constraints - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry-breaking_constraints"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking and cortical rotation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_Breaking_and_Cortical_Rotation"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking of escaping ants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking_of_escaping_ants"},{"title":"Electroweak scale - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electroweak_scale"},{"title":"Higgs mechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higgs_mechanism"}]

## Symmetry Breaking - Overview

In physics, symmetry breaking is a phenomenon where a disordered but symmetric state collapses into an ordered, but less symmetric state.(no content)This phenomenon is fundamental to quantum field theory (QFT), and further, contemporary understandings of physics.

### Types of Symmetry Breaking

Symmetry breaking can be distinguished into two types, explicit and spontaneous, characterized by whether the equations of motion fail to be invariant, or the ground state fails to be invariant.

**Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking (SSB)**: In spontaneous symmetry breaking, the equations of motion of the system are invariant, but any vacuum state (lowest energy state) is not.(no content)Phases of matter, such as crystals, magnets, and conventional superconductors, as well as simple phase transitions can be described by spontaneous symmetry breaking.

**Explicit Symmetry Breaking**: In theoretical physics, explicit symmetry breaking is the breaking of a symmetry of a theory by terms in its defining equations of motion that do not respect the symmetry, usually in situations where these symmetry-breaking terms are small.

### Applications in Physics

Symmetry breaking plays a central role in the Glashow–Weinberg–Salam model which forms part of the Standard Model modelling the electroweak sector.(no content)The 1964 PRL symmetry breaking papers were written by three teams (Robert Brout and François Englert; Peter Higgs; and Gerald Guralnik, C. Richard Hagen, and Tom Kibble) who are credited with the theory of the Higgs mechanism and the prediction of the Higgs field and Higgs boson.

### Biological Applications

In biology, symmetry breaking is the process by which uniformity is broken, or the number of points of view invariance are reduced, to generate a more structured and improbable state, where symmetry along a particular axis is lost to establish a polarity.

## Symmetry Breaking - Overview

In physics, symmetry breaking is a phenomenon where a disordered but symmetric state collapses into an ordered, but less symmetric state.(no content)This phenomenon is fundamental to quantum field theory (QFT), and further, contemporary understandings of physics.

### Types of Symmetry Breaking

Symmetry breaking can be distinguished into two types, explicit and spontaneous, characterized by whether the equations of motion fail to be invariant, or the ground state fails to be invariant.

**Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking (SSB)**: In spontaneous symmetry breaking, the equations of motion of the system are invariant, but any vacuum state (lowest energy state) is not.(no content)Phases of matter, such as crystals, magnets, and conventional superconductors, as well as simple phase transitions can be described by spontaneous symmetry breaking.

**Explicit Symmetry Breaking**: In theoretical physics, explicit symmetry breaking is the breaking of a symmetry of a theory by terms in its defining equations of motion that do not respect the symmetry, usually in situations where these symmetry-breaking terms are small.

### Applications in Physics

Symmetry breaking plays a central role in the Glashow–Weinberg–Salam model which forms part of the Standard Model modelling the electroweak sector.(no content)The 1964 PRL symmetry breaking papers were written by three teams (Robert Brout and François Englert; Peter Higgs; and Gerald Guralnik, C. Richard Hagen, and Tom Kibble) who are credited with the theory of the Higgs mechanism and the prediction of the Higgs field and Higgs boson.

### Biological Applications

In biology, symmetry breaking is the process by which uniformity is broken, or the number of points of view invariance are reduced, to generate a more structured and improbable state, where symmetry along a particular axis is lost to establish a polarity.

Web search results for query: "branch and cut algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Branch and cut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_cut"},{"title":"Branch and price - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_price"},{"title":"COIN-OR - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COIN-OR"},{"title":"Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Cutting-plane method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutting-plane_method"},{"title":"Travelling salesman problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travelling_salesman_problem"},{"title":"Branch-decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branchwidth"},{"title":"Guillotine cutting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guillotine_cutting"},{"title":"Branching factor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branching_factor"},{"title":"Bridge (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cut_arc"}]

Here's what I found about the branch and cut algorithm:

## Overview

Branch and cut is a method of combinatorial optimization for solving integer linear programs (ILPs), that is, linear programming (LP) problems where some or all the unknowns are restricted to integer values.

## How It Works

Branch and cut involves running a branch and bound algorithm and using cutting planes to tighten the linear programming relaxations. 

The algorithm operates through these key steps:

1. **Initial Relaxation**: The method solves the linear program without the integer constraint using the regular simplex algorithm.

2. **Cutting Planes**: When an optimal solution is obtained, and this solution has a non-integer value for a variable that is supposed to be integer, a cutting plane algorithm may be used to find further linear constraints which are satisfied by all feasible integer points but violated by the current fractional solution.

3. **Branching**: The problem is split into multiple (usually two) versions. The new linear programs are then solved using the simplex method and the process repeats.

4. **Pruning**: During the branch and bound process, non-integral solutions to LP relaxations serve as upper bounds and integral solutions serve as lower bounds. A node can be pruned if an upper bound is lower than an existing lower bound.

## Historical Context

In the mid-1990s Gérard Cornuéjols and co-workers showed them to be very effective in combination with branch-and-bound (called branch-and-cut) and ways to overcome numerical instabilities.(no content)Nowadays, all commercial MILP solvers use Gomory cuts in one way or another.

Based on my web search results, I found useful information about presolving. Here's what I found:

## Summary of Presolving Optimization

A pre-solver can remove redundant variables and remove or tighten constraints in optimization problems. This is a key preprocessing step used in optimization solvers.

Ivet Galabova combined her LP presolve with Julian Hall's simplex crash procedure and Huangfu Qi's dual simplex solver to solve a class of industrial LP problems faster than the best open-source solvers at the time, demonstrating the practical importance of presolving techniques in modern optimization software.

Presolving is particularly important for linear programming (LP) and mixed-integer programming (MIP) solvers, where it serves as a preprocessing phase that simplifies the problem before the main solving algorithms are applied. By reducing the problem size and tightening constraints, presolving can significantly improve the overall performance and speed of optimization solvers.

## Summary of Presolving Optimization

A pre-solver can remove redundant variables and remove or tighten constraints in optimization problems. This is a key preprocessing step used in optimization solvers.

Ivet Galabova combined her LP presolve with Julian Hall's simplex crash procedure and Huangfu Qi's dual simplex solver to solve a class of industrial LP problems faster than the best open-source solvers at the time, demonstrating the practical importance of presolving techniques in modern optimization software.

Presolving is particularly important for linear programming (LP) and mixed-integer programming (MIP) solvers, where it serves as a preprocessing phase that simplifies the problem before the main solving algorithms are applied. By reducing the problem size and tightening constraints, presolving can significantly improve the overall performance and speed of optimization solvers.

Here are the search results for "symmetry-breaking constraints":

## Main Definition

Symmetry-breaking constraints are new constraints that can be added to combinatorial problems to reduce solution time by eliminating symmetric solutions from the search space while preserving the existence of at least one solution.

## Related Concepts

The search results also reveal related symmetry-breaking concepts in different fields:

**In Physics:**
- Symmetry breaking is a phenomenon where a disordered but symmetric state collapses into an ordered, but less symmetric state.
- Explicit symmetry breaking is the breaking of a symmetry of a theory by terms in its defining equations of motion that do not respect the symmetry.

**In Combinatorial Optimization:**
The primary focus of "symmetry-breaking constraints" is in computational problem-solving, where the technique is used to improve efficiency in solving constraint satisfaction and optimization problems.

The search results indicate this is an important technique in constraint programming and computational complexity, though the Wikipedia article on the topic appears to be relatively brief. If you need more detailed information about specific applications or techniques in symmetry-breaking constraints, I could search for more targeted information.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of "The SCIP Optimization Suite 7.0" paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Type:** Contribution (the paper presents new features and enhancements in SCIP 7.0)

**Triples Extracted:** 8 entities with their relationships

The analysis identified key technologies and methodologies mentioned in the paper:

1. **Integer programming** (uses) - Core foundation for SCIP's constraint integer programming framework
2. **Linear programming** (uses) - Basis for mixed-integer linear optimization
3. **Benders decomposition** (proposes) - Improved in SCIP 7.0 with automated support
4. **Heuristic (computer science)** (proposes) - Enhanced primal heuristics in version 7.0
5. **Branch and cut** (uses) - Fundamental algorithm enhanced with improved branching rules
6. **Conflict-driven clause learning** (proposes) - Conflict analysis improvements in SCIP 7.0
7. **Symmetry-breaking constraints** (proposes) - Enhanced symmetry handling techniques
8. **Semidefinite programming** (uses) - Addressed through SCIP-SDP solver extension

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation script confirms all checks passed successfully.

Sources:
- [Integer programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming)
- [Linear programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming)
- [Benders decomposition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benders_decomposition)
- [Heuristic (computer science)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic_(computer_science))
- [Branch and cut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_cut)
- [Conflict-driven clause learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conflict-driven_clause_learning)
- [Symmetry-breaking constraints](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry-breaking_constraints)
- [Semidefinite programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semidefinite_programming)
